name: Helgafell (Þingvellir)
description:
Helgafell (not to be confused with its namesake on Snæfellsnes) is a prominent mountain located in the Þingvellir area of Southwest Iceland, rising to 338 meters above sea level. This Helgafell overlooks the historic Þingvellir National Park from the north, offering spectacular views of the UNESCO World Heritage site where Iceland's parliament, the Alþingi, was established in 930 AD. The mountain's name means 'Holy Mountain,' reflecting the sacred significance that Icelandic chieftains attributed to prominent peaks in the landscape. Helgafell serves as an excellent vantage point for understanding the dramatic geology and historical importance of the Þingvellir rift valley.

Hiking to Helgafell's summit provides one of the best panoramic views of Þingvellir National Park, including the parliamentary assembly site, Öxará river, Almannagjá rift, and Þingvallavatn lake stretching into the distance. The trail offers clear views of the tectonic rift valley where the North American and Eurasian continental plates are pulling apart at approximately 2 centimeters per year. The hike takes approximately 45-60 minutes to ascend via the marked trail from the parking area. The path winds through low vegetation and volcanic rock formations, gaining elevation steadily but manageably. The summit area features a large cairn and provides shelter from wind on blustery days. On exceptionally clear days, several glaciers including Langjökull are visible on the horizon.

Helgafell is located within Þingvellir National Park, with access from Route 36. The parking area is well-marked and located along the northern rim of the rift valley. The hike is suitable for moderately fit individuals, though proper hiking boots are recommended due to rocky terrain. Summer months (June-September) offer the most comfortable hiking conditions, though the mountain can be climbed year-round by experienced hikers. Winter ascents require crampons and ice axes due to snow and ice. The trail is maintained by park authorities and is well-signed. Þingvellir National Park charges a parking fee, which supports park maintenance and facilities. The Helgafell hike can be combined with exploring other Þingvellir attractions including the Law Rock, Silfra fissure, and Öxarárfoss waterfall.
